Scripts.script_desc: Alright, welcome to Yomimasu Japanese class!!
Before you learn Japanese you should to know about Japanese alphabets.
In Japanese has three type of alphabets
and in each alphabet have Romaji.
Romaji will translate the consonant in each alphabet into English form.
It can help you to read Japanese alphabets easily.
It devided into each line by the consonant that end with the a i u e o sound.
In first line is the single sound that consists of...
Alright, Let me ask you a little question.
What is the romaji of this alphabet ?
What is the Hiragana alphabet of this romaji ?
What is the pronunciation of this word ?
Ok, let's move to the K-line.
K-line is combining between 「k」 sound and 「a i u e o」 sound.
S-line is pronouncing 「s」 sound and 「a i u e o」 sound together.
In S-line has some special sound that you have to read carefully.
Alright, I want to know that you can remember K-line and S-line.
What is the Romaji of this alphabet ?
What is the Hiragana of this Romaji ?
Great job!!! You have passed the K-line and S-line.
I think you are ready to go to the next line.
T-line is combining between 「t」 and 「a i u e o」
In this line has two special alphabets that you need to remember.
N-line is combining between 「n」 and 「a i u e o」
What is the Romaji of this alphabet ?
What is the Romaji of this alphabet ?
What is the Romaji of this alphabet ?
What is the Romaji of this alphabet ?
What is the Romaji of this alphabet ?
Try to be better in Japanese.
H-line is combining between 「h」 and 「a i u e o」
M-line is combining between 「m」 and 「a i u e o」
I will ask you all in the past...
Can you remember all of these hehehe ?
What is the Romaji of this alphabet ?
What is the Romaji of this alphabet ?
What is the Hiragana of this picture ?
What is the Romaji of this picture ?
Ok I know you are great, let's go 'til the end!!!
Y-line is combining between 「y」 and 「a u o」
R-line is combining between 「r」 and 「a i u e o」
W-line is combining between 「w」 and 「a o」
and the last alphabet is 「ん」 n

I want to take some little test with you!

Chapter2.Name: Additional Sound in Hiragana Part 1
Chapter2.Objective: Learn About Additional Sounds: Voice and Semi-Voice Consonants.

question_choice: Combining between alphabets end up with a-sound and alphabet in Y-line.
Combining between alphabets end up with i-sound and alphabet in Y-line.

Scripts.script_desc: The next, we gonna learn about the additional sounds.
In this chapter we will learn about the voice and semi-voice consonant.
Voice consonant is the consonant that you take a breath out less than normal alphabets.
In Japanese uses 「〃」 (tenten) for voice consonant alphabets.
The alphabet line that can do the voice consonant.
Before we go to semi-voice consonant, let's do some quiz ^-^.
What will happen if you put tenten 「〃」 on alphabets in K-line?
What will happen if you put tenten 「〃」 on alphabets in S-line?
What will happen if you put tenten 「〃」 on alphabets in H-line?
YOU HAVE PASSED THE LESSON : 'VOICE CONSONANT'.
I'm proud of you. Let's go to the next lesson!!!
Semi-voice consonant is the consonant that you take a breath out more than normal alphabets.
Semi-voice consonant can use with H-line only.
What will happen if you put maru 「○」 on H-line?
Which alphabet line can be a semi-voice consonant?
YOU HAVE PASSED THE LESSON : 'SEMI-VOICE CONSONANT'.
Good luck for your post-test!! Bye bye.

test_choice: Alphabets that take more breathe to speak.

Chapter3.Name: Additional Sound in Hiragana Part 2
Chapter3.Objective: Learn About Additional Sounds: Long Vowel and Yo-on.

question_choice: Combining between alphabets end up with a-sound and alphabet in Y-line.
Combining between alphabets end up with i-sound and alphabet in Y-line.

Scripts.script_desc: After we learn about Voice and Semi-voice consonants...
Today we will learn about the next type of additional sounds in Japanese.
In japanese, every alphabet is short sound.
Long vowel sound helps to make the alphabet into a long sound.
Long vowel will using like this.
1. use 「あ」 to make the long sound with alphabets that end with a-sound.
2. use 「い」 to make the long sound with alphabets that end with i-sound.
3. use 「う」 to make the long sound with alphabets that end with u-sound.
Okay, this is easy to remember because it is the same alphabet.
But next, you must use your memory.
4. use 「い」 to make the long sound with alphabets that end with e-sound.
Be careful! some word use 「え」 to make the long sound.
5. use 「う」 to make the long sound with alphabets that end with o-sound.
Be careful! some word use 「お」 to make the long sound.
Okay, that is the Long vowel sound.
This is a question before you go to the Yo-on sound.
What alphabet that use to make a-sound longer.
What alphabet that use to make i-sound longer.
What alphabet that use to make u-sound longer.
What alphabet that use to make e-sound longer.
What alphabet that use to make o-sound longer.
YOU HAVE PASSED THE LESSON : 'LONG VOWEL'.
Practice everyday to be the best!!
And the fourth lesson of addtion sounds in Hiragana!!
Yo-on sound is the combining between the alphabets the end with i-sound and the alphabets in Y-Line.
In Japanese has written alphabets in Y-Line into a small form for identifying the Yo-on sound.
Every line has the similar pattern that end with ya-sound, yu-sound and yo-sound. The beginning sound depends on each alphabet line.
K-Line き (ki) → 「 きゃ (kya), きゅ (kyu), きょ (kyo) 」
G-Line ぎ (gi) → 「 ぎゃ (gya), ぎゅ (gyu), ぎょ (gyo) 」
S-Line さ (shi) → 「 さゃ (sha), さゅ (shu), さょ (sho) 」
Z-Line ざ (ji) → 「 ざゃ (ja), ざゅ (ju), ざょ (jo) 」
T-Line ち (chi) → 「 ちゃ (cha), ちゅ (chu), ちょ (cho) 」
N-Line に (ni) → 「 にゃ (nya), にゅ (nyu), にょ (nyo) 」
H-Line ひ (hi) → 「 ひゃ (hya), ひゅ (hyu), ひょ (hyo) 」
B-Line び (bi) → 「 びゃ (bya), びゅ (byu), びょ (byo) 」
P-Line ぴ (pi) → 「 ぴゃ (pya), ぴゅ (pyu), ぴょ (pyo) 」
M-Line み (mi) → 「 みゃ (mya), みゅ (myu), みょ (myo) 」
R-Line り (ri) → 「 りゃ (mya), り (myu), りょ (myo) 」
Don't worry, if you can't remember I will put it in alphabet chart.
the meaning of Yo-on sound and normal sound is different.
I will test you with my Yo-on questions. Are you ready?
Which alphabet cannot be the Yo-on sound.
What is the Romaji of 「ぎゅうにゅう」.
Congratulation!! You have passed Long vowel and Yo-on sound lessons.
You do the best. See you next lesson, bye ^-^.

Chapter4.Name: Additional Sound in Hiragana Part 3
Chapter4.Objective: Learn About Additional Sound: Hard Consonant.

Scripts.script_desc: This is the last lesson of additional sounds in Hiragana.
Hard consonant is crating hard stop before you say next alphabet by using small 「つ」 to represent.
The sound of small 「つ」 is depends on the following alphabets.
This sound can do only the alphabets in K-Line, S-Line, T-Line, and P-Line.
せっけん : small 「つ」 is in front of 「け」. So, the Romaji is 「sekken」.
ざっし : small 「つ」 is in front of 「し」. So, the Romaji is 「zasshi」.
きって : small 「つ」 is in front of 「て」. So, the Romaji is 「kitte」.
きっぷ : small 「つ」 is in front of 「ぷ」. So, the Romaji is 「kippu」.
Hard consonant is very easy, isn't it?
Haha Let's take some test from me!!!
Which alphabet that we use in hard consonant?
What is the sound of small 「つ」
What is the Romaji of this word?
What is the Hiragana of this word?
What is the sound of this small 「つ」
YOU HAVE PASSED THE LESSON : 'HARD CONSONANT'.
Try to practice everyday, you will be great!
I have no lesson in Hiragana to teach you.
Congratulation, you have passed all lesson in Hiragana!
Good luck in post-test and see you in Katakana lesson ^-^.

Chapter6.Name: Additional Sounds in Katakana
Chapter6.Objective: Learn About Long Vowel Form of Katakana

Scripts.script_desc: You must know the additional sounds in Katakana.
Katakana has the five additional sounds like Hiragana.
Okay! Let me explain in each additional sound.
Voice consonant, semi-voice consonant, Yo-on, and Hard consonant are the same form with Hiragana.
Voice consonant is the consonant that you take a breath out less than normal alphabets.
If you want to learn this consonant again, you can play in Yomimasu Chapter 2.
Semi-voice consonant is the consonant that you take a breath out more than normal alphabets.
If you want to learn this consonant again, you can play in Yomimasu Chapter 2.
Yo-on sound is the combining between the alphabets the end with i-sound and the alphabets in Y-Line.
If you want to learn this consonant again, you can play in Yomimasu Chapter 3.
Hard consonant is crating hard stop before you say next alphabet by using small 「ツ」 to represent.
If you want to learn this consonant again, you can play in Yomimasu Chapter 4.
But, the different is long vowel.
According to long vowel in Hiragana, The Doing of long vowel is use 「あ　い　う　え　お」 to make the sound longer.
But in Katakana is a piece of cake!!
You just put the dash 「―」 after the alphabets.
In Romaji, we use (ā, ī, ū, ē, ō) to represent the long vowel.
It's easier that Hiragana, isn't it ?
What consonant that is not familar pattern with Hiragana?
What is the represent of long vowel in Katakana?
Which word is not a long vowel word?
What is the meaning of this word? (I think you can guess)
Great! you can answer all of my question
I think you can do the post-test well.
See you next time, good luck for your post-test ^-^.

Chapter7.Name: Wi Aru Foreinā
Chapter7.Objective: Learn About How To Writing Foreigner Words.

Scripts.script_desc: Katakana has used for writing common foreign words and name of foreigner.
But every Japanese alphabets always end with 「a i u e o」 sounds.
So, because of this, new sounds have been created using katakana...
to help allow words to be made into Japanese.
Here they are all new sounds, in order of 「a i u e o」 sounds.
Ok, let me test your understanding!!
What is a Romaji of this Katakana?
What is a Romaji of this Katakana?
What is a Romaji of this Katakana?
What is a Romaji of this word?
What is a Katakana of this Romaji?
YOU HAVE UNLOCK 'NEW SOUNDS' IN ALPHABET CHART.
Ok, The next is the last lesson of this chapter and Katakana.
When you know about the new sounds, you must know how to end up the foreign words in Katakana form.
In Japanese the words always end with 「a i u e o」 sound following by alphabets.
But, some foreign words end up with many alphabets.
So, this is how to end up the foreign words in Katakana for making a nearly close sounds with the original.
1. If the sound doesn't end with 「a i u e o」 sound, use the alphabet u-sound.
2. If the sound end with 't', use '「ト」　to'.
3. If the sound end with 'd', use '「ド」　do'.
4. If the sound end with 'ch', use '「チ」　chi'.
5. If the sound end with 'ge', use '「ジ」　ji'.
6. If the sound end with 'sh', use '「シュ」 shu'.
Ok that is my test for improving your understanding.
How I can write this word in Katakana?

YOU HAVE PASSED ALL KATAKANA LESSON.
Yay!!! You have passed all Katakana test.
From the beginning, now you have many knowledge in Japanese.
Don't stop learning, you will be a professional in Japanese!
